dictionary.phrase: not worth a hill of beans
dictionary.definition: worthless.  Your advice isn’t worth a hill of beans.  This old cow isn’t worth a plugged nickel.

dictionary.phrase: not amount to a hill of beans
dictionary.definition: worthless.  Your advice isn’t worth a hill of beans.  This old cow isn’t worth a plugged nickel.
worthless.  Your advice isn’t worth a hill of beans.  This old cow isn’t worth a plugged nickel.
worthless.  Your advice isn’t worth a hill of beans.  This old cow isn’t worth a plugged nickel.

dictionary.phrase: not worth the paper it’s written on
dictionary.definition: [of a document] meaningless or without authority; of no value. That contract isn’t worth the paper it’s written on. All the signatures are forged.  Don’t take a check from that guy. It’s not worth the paper it’s written on.

dictionary.phrase: not worth the paper it’s printed on
dictionary.definition: [of a document] meaningless or without authority; of no value. That contract isn’t worth the paper it’s written on. All the signatures are forged.  Don’t take a check from that guy. It’s not worth the paper it’s written on.

a little higher in quality than someone or something.  This latest candidate we interviewed seems a notch above the rest, so let’s hire her.  That telescope is a notch better than the others in terms of magnification.

dictionary.phrase: a notch better than (someone or something)
dictionary.definition: a little higher in quality than someone or something.  This latest candidate we interviewed seems a notch above the rest, so let’s hire her.  That telescope is a notch better than the others in terms of magnification.
very thin or emaciated. Bill has lost so much weight. He’s nothing but skin and bones. Look at Bill. He’s just skin and bones.  That old horse is all skin and bones. I won’t ride it.
very thin or emaciated. Bill has lost so much weight. He’s nothing but skin and bones. Look at Bill. He’s just skin and bones.  That old horse is all skin and bones. I won’t ride it.
nothing small or unimportant.  It’s not a lot of money, but it’s nothing to sneeze at.  Our house isn’t a mansion, but it’s nothing to sneeze at.  A few thousand dollars is nothing to be sneezed at!
nothing small or unimportant.  It’s not a lot of money, but it’s nothing to sneeze at.  Our house isn’t a mansion, but it’s nothing to sneeze at.  A few thousand dollars is nothing to be sneezed at!

Inf. What is going to happen now?; What kind of new problem has arisen? _ The phone rang again, and Tom said, rising from the chair, “Now what?” _Bob: There’s a serious problem—sort of an emergency— in the mail room. Sue: What now? Bob: They’re out of stamps or something silly like that.

Inf. What is going to happen now?; What kind of new problem has arisen? _ The phone rang again, and Tom said, rising from the chair, “Now what?” _Bob: There’s a serious problem—sort of an emergency— in the mail room. Sue: What now? Bob: They’re out of stamps or something silly like that.
crazy. (*Also: as ~.) _ Don’t pay any attention to John; he’s nutty as a fruitcake.  Mary’s schemes for making money are nuttier than a fruitcake.
crazy. (*Also: as ~.) _ Don’t pay any attention to John; he’s nutty as a fruitcake.  Mary’s schemes for making money are nuttier than a fruitcake.

dictionary.phrase: nuzzle up against someone or something
dictionary.definition: [for an animal] to rub its nose against someone or something; to rub against someone or something, softly, in the manner of rubbing the nose against someone or something; to snuggle up to someone or something. (Nuzzle is related to nose.) _ The dog nuzzled up against my leg, wanting to be friends.  The dog nuzzled up to me and licked my hand.

[for an animal] to rub its nose against someone or something; to rub against someone or something, softly, in the manner of rubbing the nose against someone or something; to snuggle up to someone or something. (Nuzzle is related to nose.) _ The dog nuzzled up against my leg, wanting to be friends.  The dog nuzzled up to me and licked my hand.
a very large amount of something. The naughty student was in oceans of trouble.  After a week of vacation, there was an ocean of work to do.

dictionary.phrase: an ocean of someone or something
dictionary.definition: a very large amount of something. The naughty student was in oceans of trouble.  After a week of vacation, there was an ocean of work to do.

dictionary.phrase: of one mind (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: in agreement about someone or something.  You will have to attend one of the state universities. Your father and I are of a single mind about this.

dictionary.phrase: of a single mind (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: in agreement about someone or something.  You will have to attend one of the state universities. Your father and I are of a single mind about this.
by one’s own choice, without coercion.  I wish that Sally would choose to do it of her own accord. I’ll have to order her to do it because she won’t do it of her own free will.
by one’s own choice, without coercion.  I wish that Sally would choose to do it of her own accord. I’ll have to order her to do it because she won’t do it of her own free will.

dictionary.phrase: *off on the right foot (with someone or something)
dictionary.definition: starting out correctly; beginning something carefully and cautiously. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ This time, I want to get off on the right foot with him.  I tried to get off to a good start with my new job.

dictionary.phrase: *off to a good start (with someone or something)
dictionary.definition: starting out correctly; beginning something carefully and cautiously. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ This time, I want to get off on the right foot with him.  I tried to get off to a good start with my new job.

starting something (such as a friendship) with negative factors. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Bill and Tom got off on the wrong foot. They had a minor car accident just before they were introduced. Let’s work hard to be friends. I hate to get off on the wrong foot.

starting something (such as a friendship) with negative factors. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Bill and Tom got off on the wrong foot. They had a minor car accident just before they were introduced. Let’s work hard to be friends. I hate to get off on the wrong foot.
crazy; silly. (*Typically: be ~; go ~.) _Sometimes, Bob, I think you’re off your rocker.  Good grief, John. You’re off your nut.
crazy; silly. (*Typically: be ~; go ~.) _Sometimes, Bob, I think you’re off your rocker.  Good grief, John. You’re off your nut.
crazy; silly. (*Typically: be ~; go ~.) _Sometimes, Bob, I think you’re off your rocker.  Good grief, John. You’re off your nut.
away from the frequently traveled routes. (*Typically: be ~; go ~; travel ~.) _ We found a nice little Italian restaurant off the beaten track.
away from the frequently traveled routes. (*Typically: be ~; go ~; travel ~.) _ We found a nice little Italian restaurant off the beaten track.

dictionary.phrase: old enough to be someone’s mother
dictionary.definition: as old as someone’s parents. (Usually a way of saying that a person is too old.) _ You can’t go out with Bill. He’s old enough to be your father! _ He married a woman who is old enough to be his mother.

dictionary.phrase: old enough to be someone’s father
dictionary.definition: as old as someone’s parents. (Usually a way of saying that a person is too old.) _ You can’t go out with Bill. He’s old enough to be your father! _ He married a woman who is old enough to be his mother.

uncertain; indecisive.  I don’t know about the picnic. It’s on again, off again. It depends on the weather.  Jane doesn’t know if she’s going to look for a new job. She’s off again, on again about it.

uncertain; indecisive.  I don’t know about the picnic. It’s on again, off again. It depends on the weather.  Jane doesn’t know if she’s going to look for a new job. She’s off again, on again about it.
occasionally; erratically; now and again.  I feel better off and on, but I’m not well yet.  He only came to class on and off.
occasionally; erratically; now and again.  I feel better off and on, but I’m not well yet.  He only came to class on and off.
really; indeed; in fact. (Used as an intensifier after who, what, when, where, how.) _What on earth do you mean? _How in creation do you expect me to do that? _Who in the world do you think you are?
really; indeed; in fact. (Used as an intensifier after who, what, when, where, how.) _What on earth do you mean? _How in creation do you expect me to do that? _Who in the world do you think you are?
really; indeed; in fact. (Used as an intensifier after who, what, when, where, how.) _What on earth do you mean? _How in creation do you expect me to do that? _Who in the world do you think you are?
for no reason; absolutely not. On no account will I lend you the money.  Will I say I’m sorry? Not on any account.
for no reason; absolutely not. On no account will I lend you the money.  Will I say I’m sorry? Not on any account.
recorded for future reference.  We had the coldest winter on record last year.  This is the fastest race on record.
recorded for future reference.  We had the coldest winter on record last year.  This is the fastest race on record.

[of an idea or proposal] on an unstable or questionable foundation; [of an idea or proposal] founded on a risky premise.  When you suggest that we are to blame, you are on shaky ground. There is no evidence that we are at fault.  The case for relying solely on nuclear energy seems to be on dangerous ground.

[of an idea or proposal] on an unstable or questionable foundation; [of an idea or proposal] founded on a risky premise.  When you suggest that we are to blame, you are on shaky ground. There is no evidence that we are at fault.  The case for relying solely on nuclear energy seems to be on dangerous ground.
Inf. harassing someone about a personal problem; annoying someone. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; keep ~.) _ I’ll get on Tom’s case about being late so much.  I’m sorry, I won’t get on your case anymore.
Inf. harassing someone about a personal problem; annoying someone. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; keep ~.) _ I’ll get on Tom’s case about being late so much.  I’m sorry, I won’t get on your case anymore.
generally; usually.  On the average, you can expect about a 10 percent failure rate.  This report looks OK, on average.
generally; usually.  On the average, you can expect about a 10 percent failure rate.  This report looks OK, on average.

having the most advanced technology; knowing about the most advanced technology. (Alludes to the cutting edge of a sword.) _ This gadget is brand new. It’s really on the bleeding edge.  Tom is on the leading edge when it comes to optical storage technology.

having the most advanced technology; knowing about the most advanced technology. (Alludes to the cutting edge of a sword.) _ This gadget is brand new. It’s really on the bleeding edge.  Tom is on the leading edge when it comes to optical storage technology.
not operating; not operating correctly.  This vacuum cleaner is on the fritz. Let’s get it fixed.  How long has it been on the blink?
not operating; not operating correctly.  This vacuum cleaner is on the fritz. Let’s get it fixed.  How long has it been on the blink?
in someone’s favor. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ I tried to get on the good side of the teacher, but that teacher has no good side.  First of all, don’t try to get on the boss’s good side.
in someone’s favor. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ I tried to get on the good side of the teacher, but that teacher has no good side.  First of all, don’t try to get on the boss’s good side.
in a difficult position; subject to much attention or criticism.  I was really in the hot seat for a while.  Now that John is on the hot seat, no one is paying any attention to what I do.
in a difficult position; subject to much attention or criticism.  I was really in the hot seat for a while.  Now that John is on the hot seat, no one is paying any attention to what I do.
exactly right; in exactly the right place; in exactly the right amount (of money).  That’s a good answer, Bob. You’re right on the money.  This project is going to be finished right on the nose.
exactly right; in exactly the right place; in exactly the right amount (of money).  That’s a good answer, Bob. You’re right on the money.  This project is going to be finished right on the nose.

dictionary.phrase: on the point of doing something
dictionary.definition: ready to start doing something.  I was just on the point of going out the door.  We were almost at the point of buying a new car.

dictionary.phrase: at the point of doing something
dictionary.definition: ready to start doing something.  I was just on the point of going out the door.  We were almost at the point of buying a new car.
speaking on the telephone. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _She’s on the phone but won’t be long.  Please take a seat while I’m on the phone. Get on the phone and call him back immediately!
speaking on the telephone. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _She’s on the phone but won’t be long.  Please take a seat while I’m on the phone. Get on the phone and call him back immediately!

dictionary.phrase: *on the trail of someone or something
dictionary.definition: seeking someone or something; about to find someone or something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _I’m on the trail of a new can opener that is supposed to be easier to use.  I spent all morning on the track of a vendor who can meet our requirements.

dictionary.phrase: *on the track of someone or something
dictionary.definition: seeking someone or something; about to find someone or something. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _I’m on the trail of a new can opener that is supposed to be easier to use.  I spent all morning on the track of a vendor who can meet our requirements.

dictionary.phrase: on the verge of doing something
dictionary.definition: at the very beginning of doing something; just about to do something.  Bill was on the verge of leaving town when he found a job.  Susan was on the verge of laughter, so she left the lecture hall.
at the very beginning of doing something; just about to do something.  Bill was on the verge of leaving town when he found a job.  Susan was on the verge of laughter, so she left the lecture hall.

[for someone’s name to be] on a list of people waiting for an opportunity to do something.  I couldn’t get a seat on the plane, but I got on the waiting list.  There is no room for you, but we can put your name on the waiting list.

[for someone’s name to be] on a list of people waiting for an opportunity to do something.  I couldn’t get a seat on the plane, but I got on the waiting list.  There is no room for you, but we can put your name on the waiting list.

dictionary.phrase: *on the way (to something or some place)
dictionary.definition: moving toward a place; advancing toward a new status or condition. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Is he here yet or is he on the way? _ Mary is better now and on the way to recovery. She’s now on the way to San Francisco.  Yes, she’s on her way.

dictionary.phrase: *on one’s way (to something or some place)
dictionary.definition: moving toward a place; advancing toward a new status or condition. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Is he here yet or is he on the way? _ Mary is better now and on the way to recovery. She’s now on the way to San Francisco.  Yes, she’s on her way.
out of favor with someone. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Don’t get on the wrong side of her.  I do what I can not to get on the wrong side of people.
out of favor with someone. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ Don’t get on the wrong side of her.  I do what I can not to get on the wrong side of people.
Sl. imperative. Get out of here!; Get on your bike and get out! _ What a bad joke! No puns allowed here! On your bike! _ That was a ridiculous remark. Go to your room!
Sl. imperative. Get out of here!; Get on your bike and get out! _ What a bad joke! No puns allowed here! On your bike! _ That was a ridiculous remark. Go to your room!

dictionary.phrase: on your mark, get set, go
dictionary.definition: [in preparing to start a race involving speed] move to the starting point, get set to move, go.  Runners on your mark, get set, go.
[in preparing to start a race involving speed] move to the starting point, get set to move, go.  Runners on your mark, get set, go.

dictionary.phrase: Once a priest, always a priest.
dictionary.definition: Prov. A person who has done a certain kind of job will always have the characteristics of people who do that job, even after he or she no longer does that kind of work. (This can be applied to many different occupations.) _ Alan: My cousin left the clergy, but boy! He still preaches at me all the time. Jane: Once a priest, always a priest, huh?

dictionary.phrase: Once a whore, always a whore.
dictionary.definition: Prov. A person who has done a certain kind of job will always have the characteristics of people who do that job, even after he or she no longer does that kind of work. (This can be applied to many different occupations.) _ Alan: My cousin left the clergy, but boy! He still preaches at me all the time. Jane: Once a priest, always a priest, huh?

Please do it one more time.  Mary: You sang that line beautifully, Fred. Now, once more. Fred: I’m really tired of all this rehearsing.  John (finishing practicing his speech): How was that? Sue: Good! One more time, though. John: I’m getting bored with it.

Please do it one more time.  Mary: You sang that line beautifully, Fred. Now, once more. Fred: I’m really tired of all this rehearsing.  John (finishing practicing his speech): How was that? Sue: Good! One more time, though. John: I’m getting bored with it.
a chance that will never occur again in one’s lifetime. This is a once-in-a-lifetime chance. Don’t miss it.  She offered me a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, but I turned it down.
a chance that will never occur again in one’s lifetime. This is a once-in-a-lifetime chance. Don’t miss it.  She offered me a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, but I turned it down.

the first one, then the next one, then the next one, etc.; each in turn. I have to deal with problems one by one. I can’t handle them all at once.  Okay, just take things one at a time.  The children came into the room one by one.

the first one, then the next one, then the next one, etc.; each in turn. I have to deal with problems one by one. I can’t handle them all at once.  Okay, just take things one at a time.  The children came into the room one by one.

a phrase introducing a parting comment or the last item in a list. John: One final word—keep your chin up. Mary: Good advice! _And one final thing, don’t haul around a lot of expensive camera stuff. It just tells the thieves who to rob.

a phrase introducing a parting comment or the last item in a list. John: One final word—keep your chin up. Mary: Good advice! _And one final thing, don’t haul around a lot of expensive camera stuff. It just tells the thieves who to rob.
nearly unique; one of a very few.  He’s a great guy. He’s one in million. Mary’s one in a hundred— such a hard worker.
nearly unique; one of a very few.  He’s a great guy. He’s one in million. Mary’s one in a hundred— such a hard worker.
nearly unique; one of a very few.  He’s a great guy. He’s one in million. Mary’s one in a hundred— such a hard worker.

dictionary.phrase: one jump ahead (of someone or something)
dictionary.definition: one step in advance of someone or something. Try to stay one jump ahead of the competition.  If you’re one move ahead, you’re well prepared to deal with problems. Then, nothing is a surprise.

dictionary.phrase: one move ahead (of someone or something)
dictionary.definition: one step in advance of someone or something. Try to stay one jump ahead of the competition.  If you’re one move ahead, you’re well prepared to deal with problems. Then, nothing is a surprise.
one’s heart flutters or palpitates; one has a strong emotional reaction.  Whenever I’m near you, my heart skips a beat.  When the racehorse fell, my heart missed a beat.
one’s heart flutters or palpitates; one has a strong emotional reaction.  Whenever I’m near you, my heart skips a beat.  When the racehorse fell, my heart missed a beat.
one’s signature. Just put your John Henry on this line, and we’ll bring your new car around.
one’s signature. Just put your John Henry on this line, and we’ll bring your new car around.

dictionary.phrase: One swallow does not make a summer.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You should not assume that something is true just because you have seen one piece of evidence for it.  Amanda: I got a good grade on this quiz! My troubles in school are over. Nancy: One swallow does not a summer make.

dictionary.phrase: One swallow does not a summer make.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You should not assume that something is true just because you have seen one piece of evidence for it.  Amanda: I got a good grade on this quiz! My troubles in school are over. Nancy: One swallow does not a summer make.
to seep out of someone or something.  The heavy oil oozed out from the hole in the barrel.  Some blood was oozing out of his nose.
to seep out of someone or something.  The heavy oil oozed out from the hole in the barrel.  Some blood was oozing out of his nose.
to gain access to opportunity or influence (for someone).  Morris was able to open a few doors for Mary and get her an interview with the president.
to gain access to opportunity or influence (for someone).  Morris was able to open a few doors for Mary and get her an interview with the president.

dictionary.phrase: open up (about someone or something) (with someone)
dictionary.definition: to speak freely about someone or something; to speak a great deal about someone or something.  After a while, he began to open up about his disagreements.  He opened up with us about the accident.  She opened up on Fred with Alice.

dictionary.phrase: open up (on someone or something) (with someone)
dictionary.definition: to speak freely about someone or something; to speak a great deal about someone or something.  After a while, he began to open up about his disagreements.  He opened up with us about the accident.  She opened up on Fred with Alice.
to tell [everything] to someone; to confess to someone.  If she would only open up to me, perhaps I could help her.  She just won’t open up. Everything is “private.”
to tell [everything] to someone; to confess to someone.  If she would only open up to me, perhaps I could help her.  She just won’t open up. Everything is “private.”
to give commands to someone. I don’t like for someone to order me about.  Don’t order me around!
to give commands to someone. I don’t like for someone to order me about.  Don’t order me around!

dictionary.phrase: order someone out of some place
dictionary.definition: to command that someone leave a place.  The cook ordered Judy out of the kitchen.  The teacher ordered out all the kids.
to command that someone leave a place.  The cook ordered Judy out of the kitchen.  The teacher ordered out all the kids.

dictionary.phrase: the other side of the tracks
dictionary.definition: the poor part of a town or city.  He was a rich boy, and she was a girl from the other side of the tracks.  You don’t want to buy a house in that neighborhood. It’s on the wrong side of the tracks.

dictionary.phrase: the wrong side of the tracks
dictionary.definition: the poor part of a town or city.  He was a rich boy, and she was a girl from the other side of the tracks.  You don’t want to buy a house in that neighborhood. It’s on the wrong side of the tracks.

Cliché if things stay the way they are now; if there are no complications from other factors.  Other things being equal, we should have no trouble getting your order to you on time. I anticipate no problems, all things being equal.

Cliché if things stay the way they are now; if there are no complications from other factors.  Other things being equal, we should have no trouble getting your order to you on time. I anticipate no problems, all things being equal.

1. Fig. unconscious.  I fell and hit my head. I was out cold for about a minute.  Tom fainted! He’s out like a light! 2. Fig. intoxicated.  Four beers and he was out cold.  He sat in his chair at the table, out cold. 3. Fig. sound asleep. After a few minutes of tossing and turning, she was out like a light.

1. Fig. unconscious.  I fell and hit my head. I was out cold for about a minute.  Tom fainted! He’s out like a light! 2. Fig. intoxicated.  Four beers and he was out cold.  He sat in his chair at the table, out cold. 3. Fig. sound asleep. After a few minutes of tossing and turning, she was out like a light.
in evidence in some large amount. (*Typically: be ~; come ~.) _ The sidewalk salesmen are out in droves today.  The ants were out in large numbers at the picnic.
in evidence in some large amount. (*Typically: be ~; come ~.) _ The sidewalk salesmen are out in droves today.  The ants were out in large numbers at the picnic.
breathing fast and hard; gasping for breath. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ I ran so much that I got out of breath.  Mary gets out of wind when she climbs stairs.
breathing fast and hard; gasping for breath. (*Typically: be ~; get ~.) _ I ran so much that I got out of breath.  Mary gets out of wind when she climbs stairs.
out of balance; crooked or tilted. (*Typically: be ~; get ~; knock something ~.) _ John, your tie is sort of off-kilter. Let me fix it.  Please straighten the picture on the wall. It’s out of kilter.

to be silly and senseless; to be crazy and irrational. (*Typically: be ~; go ~.) _ Why did you do that? You must be out of your mind! _ Don’t drive so fast, Tom! You have to be out of your head!
to be silly and senseless; to be crazy and irrational. (*Typically: be ~; go ~.) _ Why did you do that? You must be out of your mind! _ Don’t drive so fast, Tom! You have to be out of your head!

not in good physical condition. I get out of breath when I run because I’m out of shape.  Keep exercising regularly, or you’ll get out of condition.
not in good physical condition. I get out of breath when I run because I’m out of shape.  Keep exercising regularly, or you’ll get out of condition.
not fashionable; oldfashioned; obsolete. John’s clothes are really out of style. He doesn’t care if his clothes are out of fashion.
not fashionable; oldfashioned; obsolete. John’s clothes are really out of style. He doesn’t care if his clothes are out of fashion.
long term; over a long period of time.  Over the long haul, this model will prove best.  This will last in the long haul.
long term; over a long period of time.  Over the long haul, this model will prove best.  This will last in the long haul.
long term; over a long period of time.  Over the long haul, this model will prove best.  This will last in the long haul.

for the immediate future. Over the short haul, you’d be better off to put your money in the bank.  Over the short haul, you may wish you had done something different. But things will work out all right.

to give someone too much of some substance, usually a drug.  The police say he overdosed on heroine.  Sam overdosed his sister on the cough medicine.  She overdosed herself with aspirin.

to walk around nervously or anxiously. Stop pacing around and sit down. There is no need to pace about.
to walk around nervously or anxiously. Stop pacing around and sit down. There is no need to pace about.
to walk over and over the same short route nervously or anxiously.  The leopard paced back and forth in its cage.  I paced up and down, worrying about a variety of things.
to walk over and over the same short route nervously or anxiously.  The leopard paced back and forth in its cage.  I paced up and down, worrying about a variety of things.
to provide a burst of energy, power, or excitement.  Wow, this spicy food really packs a wallop.  I put a special kind of gasoline in my car because I thought it would pack a punch. It didn’t.

dictionary.phrase: pack someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to press or push someone or something into something; to manage to get a lot of things or people into a place.  The boys packed a lot of kids into a telephone booth as a gag.  They packed in a lot of kids.

to press or push someone or something into something; to manage to get a lot of things or people into a place.  The boys packed a lot of kids into a telephone booth as a gag.  They packed in a lot of kids.

a very annoying thing or person. (Crude. Potentially offensive. Use only with discretion. An elaboration of pain. Use caution with ass. Butt is less offensive. Rear is euphemistic.) _ That guy is a real pain in the ass.  Things like that give me a pain in the butt.

a very annoying thing or person. (Crude. Potentially offensive. Use only with discretion. An elaboration of pain. Use caution with ass. Butt is less offensive. Rear is euphemistic.) _ That guy is a real pain in the ass.  Things like that give me a pain in the butt.

a very annoying thing or person. (Crude. Potentially offensive. Use only with discretion. An elaboration of pain. Use caution with ass. Butt is less offensive. Rear is euphemistic.) _ That guy is a real pain in the ass.  Things like that give me a pain in the butt.
to apply a design or picture to something, using paint.  Joel painted the portrait onto a large sheet of plywood.  He painted on some leaves and f lowers too.
to apply a design or picture to something, using paint.  Joel painted the portrait onto a large sheet of plywood.  He painted on some leaves and f lowers too.
looking sick. (The around can be replaced with about.) _ John is looking a little pale around the gills. What’s wrong? _ Oh, I feel a little green about the gills.
looking sick. (The around can be replaced with about.) _ John is looking a little pale around the gills. What’s wrong? _ Oh, I feel a little green about the gills.

very pale. (*Also: as ~.) _ Laura came into the room, as pale as a ghost. “What happened?” her friends gasped.  What’s the matter? You’re pale as death!
very pale. (*Also: as ~.) _ Laura came into the room, as pale as a ghost. “What happened?” her friends gasped.  What’s the matter? You’re pale as death!
to appear to be deficient in comparison to something else.  My work pales by comparison with yours. You are a real pro.
to appear to be deficient in comparison to something else.  My work pales by comparison with yours. You are a real pro.

dictionary.phrase: palm someone or something off† (on someone) (as someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to give someone or something to someone as a gift that appears to be someone or something desirable. (As if the gift had been concealed in one’s palm until it was gotten rid of.) _ Are you trying to palm that annoying client off on me as a hot prospect? _ Don’t palm off that pest on me.  Please don’t pass that problem off on me as a challenge. Don’t pass it off on me! _Don’t pawn it off on me as something of value.

dictionary.phrase: pass someone or something off† (on someone) (as someone or something)

(As if the gift had been concealed in one’s palm until it was gotten rid of.) _ Are you trying to palm that annoying client off on me as a hot prospect? _ Don’t palm off that pest on me.  Please don’t pass that problem off on me as a challenge. Don’t pass it off on me! _Don’t pawn it off on me as something of value.

Please don’t pass that problem off on me as a challenge. Don’t pass it off on me! _Don’t pawn it off on me as something of value.
Inf. Excuse my use of swear words or taboo words. (Does not refer to real French.) _Pardon my French, but this is a hell of a day. What she needs is a kick in the ass, if you’ll excuse my French.

to cut something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ See if you can pare a bit of this extra wood off the edge of the base of this pillar.  Pare off some of the wood.
to cut something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ See if you can pare a bit of this extra wood off the edge of the base of this pillar.  Pare off some of the wood.
Euph. to die.  My aunt passed away last month.  When I pass on, I won’t care about the funeral.
Euph. to die.  My aunt passed away last month.  When I pass on, I won’t care about the funeral.

1. to send something down a line of people to someone. (Each person hands it to the next.) _ Please pass this down to Mary at the end of the row. Pass down this box to Mary. 2. to will something to someone.  My grandfather passed this watch down to me.  He passed on the watch to me.

1. to send something down a line of people to someone. (Each person hands it to the next.) _ Please pass this down to Mary at the end of the row. Pass down this box to Mary. 2. to will something to someone.  My grandfather passed this watch down to me.  He passed on the watch to me.
to turn in or hand in something, such as a school assignment, paper, etc., to someone.  They were told to pass their papers in to the teacher.  Hand in your papers to me.
to turn in or hand in something, such as a school assignment, paper, etc., to someone.  They were told to pass their papers in to the teacher.  Hand in your papers to me.

to get rid of something deceptively by giving or selling it to someone as something else.  I passed the rhinestone off on John as a diamond. Don’t try to pass that fake off on me! _He couldn’t pass off the stone on the clever jeweler.

to get rid of something deceptively by giving or selling it to someone as something else.  I passed the rhinestone off on John as a diamond. Don’t try to pass that fake off on me! _He couldn’t pass off the stone on the clever jeweler.

[for a thought] to come to mind briefly; [for an idea] to occur to someone.  Let me tell you what just crossed my mind. As you were speaking, something passed through my mind that I’d like to discuss.

[for a thought] to come to mind briefly; [for an idea] to occur to someone.  Let me tell you what just crossed my mind. As you were speaking, something passed through my mind that I’d like to discuss.
to pat someone’s back to show praise. The coach patted each player on the back after the game.

dictionary.phrase: give someone a pat on the back
dictionary.definition: to pat someone’s back to show praise. The coach patted each player on the back after the game.

dictionary.phrase: pay an arm and a leg (for something)
dictionary.definition: to pay too much [money] for something.  I hate to have to pay an arm and a leg for a tank of gas.  If you shop around, you won’t have to pay an arm and a leg.  Why should you pay through the nose?
to pay too much [money] for something.  I hate to have to pay an arm and a leg for a tank of gas.  If you shop around, you won’t have to pay an arm and a leg.  Why should you pay through the nose?

to give someone a false compliment that is really an insult or criticism. John said that he had never seen me looking better. I think he was paying me a left-handed compliment.  I’d prefer that someone insulted me directly. I hate it when someone pays me a backhanded compliment—unless it’s a joke.

to visit someone or something. Bill paid a visit to his aunt in Seattle.  Please pay a visit to our house whenever you are in town.

dictionary.phrase: pay a visit to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to visit someone or something. Bill paid a visit to his aunt in Seattle.  Please pay a visit to our house whenever you are in town.
to pay an amount of money into an account.  Mary paid forty dollars into my account by mistake.  She paid in a lot of money.  I have an account here and I want to pay something in.
to pay an amount of money into an account.  Mary paid forty dollars into my account by mistake.  She paid in a lot of money.  I have an account here and I want to pay something in.
to remove the outside surface layer from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ She carefully peeled the skin off the apple.  She peeled off the apple’s skin.
to remove the outside surface layer from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ She carefully peeled the skin off the apple.  She peeled off the apple’s skin.
to think of someone in a certain way.  Susan pegged the new employee as a lazy worker.  I had you pegged as an angry rebel before I got to know you.
to think of someone in a certain way.  Susan pegged the new employee as a lazy worker.  I had you pegged as an angry rebel before I got to know you.

a person who is completely unknown [to oneself]. I was stopped on the street by a perfect stranger who wanted to know my name.  If a total stranger asked me such a personal question, I am sure I would not answer!

a person who is completely unknown [to oneself]. I was stopped on the street by a perfect stranger who wanted to know my name.  If a total stranger asked me such a personal question, I am sure I would not answer!
to allow someone to enter something or some place.  They would not permit me in the dining room since I had no tie.  They would not permit in that bunch of rowdy brats or any other of her friends.

dictionary.phrase: phase someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to work someone or something into use or service gradually. They decided to phase Ruth into the job little by little. They phased in Ruth over a long period of time.
to work someone or something into use or service gradually. They decided to phase Ruth into the job little by little. They phased in Ruth over a long period of time.

dictionary.phrase: phase someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to work someone or something out of use or service or out of a group gradually.  We are going to have to phase you out of the job of treasurer.  They phased out the unneeded workers.
to work someone or something out of use or service or out of a group gradually.  We are going to have to phase you out of the job of treasurer.  They phased out the unneeded workers.
phony; bogus. (*Also: as ~.) _This guy’s as phony as a three-dollar bill. The whole deal stinks. It’s as queer as a three-dollar bill.
phony; bogus. (*Also: as ~.) _This guy’s as phony as a three-dollar bill. The whole deal stinks. It’s as queer as a three-dollar bill.
to start a fight or argument with someone on purpose.  Are you trying to pick a fight with me? _ Max intended to pick a quarrel with Lefty.
to start a fight or argument with someone on purpose.  Are you trying to pick a fight with me? _ Max intended to pick a quarrel with Lefty.

dictionary.phrase: pick on someone your own size
dictionary.definition: to abuse someone who is big enough to fight back.  Go pick on somebody your own size! _Wilbur should leave his little brother alone and pick on someone his own size.

dictionary.phrase: pick on somebody your own size
dictionary.definition: to abuse someone who is big enough to fight back.  Go pick on somebody your own size! _Wilbur should leave his little brother alone and pick on someone his own size.

1. to move along a route full of obstacles; to travel, usually on foot, through an area of heavy vegetation or through a crowd of people or things.  When the grandchildren visit, I have to pick my way through the toys on the f loor.  We slowly picked our way through the thorny bushes to get to the ripe raspberries. 2. to work slowly and meticulously through something. My teacher said he couldn’t even pick his way through my report. It was just too confusing.  I spent an hour picking my way through the state tax forms.

dictionary.phrase: pick someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: 1. to lift or pull someone or something out of something. The mother picked her child out of the fray and took him home.  I picked out the mushrooms before eating the soup. 2. to select someone or something out of an offering of selections.  I picked Jerry out of all the boys in the class.  I picked out Jerry.

I picked out the mushrooms before eating the soup. 2. to select someone or something out of an offering of selections.  I picked Jerry out of all the boys in the class.  I picked out Jerry.
to pay the bill. Whenever we go out, my father picks up the tab. Order whatever you want. The company is picking up the check.

Sl. a share in the activity or the profits. (Especially of a business scheme or gambling activity.) _ If you get in on that real estate deal, I want a piece, too.  Deal Tom in. He wants a piece of the action.

to bunch people into something in a disorderly fashion. She piled the kids into the van and headed off for school.  She piled in the kids and closed the doors. Pile them in and let’s go.  They piled themselves into the car and sped off.

dictionary.phrase: pile someone or something on(to) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to heap people or things onto someone or something.  The wrestler piled the referee onto his unconscious opponent. We piled the kids on the heap of leaves we had raked up.  Pile on the chili! What’s a hot dog without chili?

someone or something that consistently provides moral, emotional, or financial support as does a pillar. My parents are my pillars of support.  John looked to God as his pillar of strength.

to steer or guide something into something. (Usually refers to steering a ship.) _ We need to signal for a pilot to pilot our ship into the harbor.  Fred piloted in the freighter.

to steer or guide something out of something. (Usually refers to steering a ship.) _ The chubby little man with a pipe piloted the huge ship out of the harbor.  The storm made it very difficult to pilot the ship out.  Help me pilot out this old tub.

dictionary.phrase: pin one’s faith on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to fasten one’s faith or hope to someone or something.  Don’t pin your faith on Tom. He can’t always do exactly what you want.  He pinned his hopes on being rescued soon.

dictionary.phrase: pin one’s hopes on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to fasten one’s faith or hope to someone or something.  Don’t pin your faith on Tom. He can’t always do exactly what you want.  He pinned his hopes on being rescued soon.

to demand and receive a firm answer from someone to some question. (Alludes to shifting from answer to answer; commit to one answer or another.) _ I tried to pin him down on a time and place, something but he was very evasive. Don’t try to pin down the mayor on anything! _ I want to nail her down on a meeting time.

to attach or affix something with nails or pins. Pin the pattern down temporarily.  Nail down this piece of f looring every 12 inches.

to attach something to something, for display, with pins.  I pinned the picture up onto the bulletin board where everyone could see it.  I pinned up the picture.

to sever something from something by pinching. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Pinch the buds off the lower branches so the one at the top will bloom. Pinch off the lower buds.

to long for or grieve for someone or something. Bob pined after Doris for weeks after she left. Dan is still pining for his lost dog.  There is no point in pining over Claire.

to conduct a liquid or a gas into some place through a pipe.  An excellent delivery system piped oxygen into every hospital room. They piped in oxygen to every room.  They piped it in.

to arouse interest; to arouse curiosity.  The advertisement piqued my curiosity about the product. The professor tried to pique the students’ interest in French literature.

dictionary.phrase: pitch someone or something out (of) something
dictionary.definition: to throw someone or something out of something or some place. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _The usher pitched the drunk out of the theater.  The usher pitched out the annoying person.
to throw someone or something out of something or some place. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _The usher pitched the drunk out of the theater.  The usher pitched out the annoying person.
to toss or throw something into something.  Please pitch your aluminum cans into this container.  She pitched in the can.

dictionary.phrase: place someone or something before someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. to put someone or something in front of someone or something, especially in a line.  The teacher placed George before Bob, because Bob was a little taller.  Tom placed himself before the group and began to speak. 2. to consider someone or something more important than someone or something.  I am sorry, but I place my wife and her welfare before yours! _ He places his job before his family!

dictionary.phrase: put someone or something before someone or something
dictionary.definition: 1. to put someone or something in front of someone or something, especially in a line.  The teacher placed George before Bob, because Bob was a little taller.  Tom placed himself before the group and began to speak. 2. to consider someone or something more important than someone or something.  I am sorry, but I place my wife and her welfare before yours! _ He places his job before his family!
to spread a substance onto something.  She plastered great globs of the jam onto the toast.  She plastered on lots of butter.
to spread a substance onto something.  She plastered great globs of the jam onto the toast.  She plastered on lots of butter.
to serve as a major part of some situation or event.  The incredible amount of duplicative paperwork played a large part in my decision to find employment elsewhere.
